tests.title: Given a primitive type, we have a set of expected behaviors for that type. Eg: Given number 42, it has expected behaviors such as we can do math on that. Given a string '42', we can expect it to get its individual chars and print to console.
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types Given a primitive type, we have a set of expected behaviors for that type. Eg: Given number 42, it has expected behaviors such as we can do math on that. Given a string '42', we can expect it to get its individual chars and print to console.

tests.title:
Classified into
			undefined
			null 
			string 
			number 
			boolean 
			object 
				function (subtype of object - special callable object)
			symbol (ES6)
			bigint (ES6)
tests.fullTitle:
Primitive Types Classified into
			undefined
			null 
			string 
			number 
			boolean 
			object 
				function (subtype of object - special callable object)
			symbol (ES6)
			bigint (ES6)

tests.title: As Javascript is dynamically typed language, it has type of a VALUE that the variable is currently holding
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types As Javascript is dynamically typed language, it has type of a VALUE that the variable is currently holding

tests.title: when typeof operator used on a variable, returns the value type that the variable is currently holding
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types when typeof operator used on a variable, returns the value type that the variable is currently holding

tests.title: typeof operator will always return a string. It will not actually return the primitive type of the variable
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types typeof operator will always return a string. It will not actually return the primitive type of the variable

tests.title: returns string 'number' when used typeof operator on number
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types returns string 'number' when used typeof operator on number
tests.code: assert.equal(typeof 42, 'number');

tests.title: returns string 'string' when used typeof operator on string
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types returns string 'string' when used typeof operator on string
tests.code: assert.equal(typeof '42', 'string');

tests.title: returns string 'boolean' when used typeof operator on boolean
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types returns string 'boolean' when used typeof operator on boolean
tests.code: assert.equal(typeof true, 'boolean');

tests.title: returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on object
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on object
tests.code: assert.equal(typeof { a: 1 }, 'object');

tests.title: returns string 'function' when used typeof operator on function
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types returns string 'function' when used typeof operator on function
tests.code: assert.equal(typeof function(){}, 'function');

suites.title: null - a historical bug in javascript

tests.title: returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on null, while we may expect that it should return 'null'. This is a bug in javascript
tests.fullTitle: null - a historical bug in javascript returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on null, while we may expect that it should return 'null'. This is a bug in javascript
tests.code: assert.equal(typeof null, 'object');

tests.title: returns string 'undefined' when used typeof operator on variable that is not DECLARED
tests.fullTitle: undeclared vs undefined returns string 'undefined' when used typeof operator on variable that is not DECLARED
tests.code: assert.equal(typeof anyVarThatIsNotDeclared, 'undefined');

tests.title: returns string 'undefined' when used typeof operator on variable that is not DEFINED
tests.fullTitle: undeclared vs undefined returns string 'undefined' when used typeof operator on variable that is not DEFINED
tests.code:
var foo;
assert.equal(typeof foo, 'undefined');

tests.title: It is a separate partition from numbers, where it grow upto memory limit of the system. It can't be mixed and matched with regular numbers.
tests.fullTitle: bigint It is a separate partition from numbers, where it grow upto memory limit of the system. It can't be mixed and matched with regular numbers.

tests.title: returns string 'symbol' when used typeof operator on symbol
tests.fullTitle: symbol returns string 'symbol' when used typeof operator on symbol
tests.code:
var symbol = Symbol();
assert.equal(typeof symbol, 'symbol');

tests.title: As mentioned earlier, given a primitive type, we have a set of expected behaviors for that type. Definitely, a function has some set of expected behaviors. Eg: We can call a function
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Type - function As mentioned earlier, given a primitive type, we have a set of expected behaviors for that type. Definitely, a function has some set of expected behaviors. Eg: We can call a function

tests.title: is not actually a primitive type. It is a subtype of object primitive. It is also referred to as callable object
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Type - function is not actually a primitive type. It is a subtype of object primitive. It is also referred to as callable object

tests.title: returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on other built in objects like Array, Date, Regular expression, etc
tests.fullTitle: Other in-built types are objects returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on other built in objects like Array, Date, Regular expression, etc

tests.title: returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on arrays
tests.fullTitle: Other in-built types are objects returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on arrays
tests.code:
var array = [];
assert.equal(typeof array, 'object');

tests.title: returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on dates
tests.fullTitle: Other in-built types are objects returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on dates
tests.code:
var date = new Date();
assert.equal(typeof date, 'object');

tests.title: returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on regular expressions
tests.fullTitle: Other in-built types are objects returns string 'object' when used typeof operator on regular expressions
tests.code:
var pattern = /ab/gi;
assert.equal(typeof pattern, 'object');

tests.title: should return 'undefined' when the variable is not yet declared or declared, but currently has no value
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types - Examples should return 'undefined' when the variable is not yet declared or declared, but currently has no value
tests.code:
var a;
assert.equal(typeof a, 'undefined');

tests.title: should return 'string', when typeof operation is assigned to a variable, because typeof always return string.
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types - Examples should return 'string', when typeof operation is assigned to a variable, because typeof always return string.
tests.code:
var output = typeof anyVarThatIsNotDeclaredOrNotDeclared;
assert.equal(typeof output, 'string');

tests.title: should return 'string' if typeof operator is used on another typeof operation.
tests.fullTitle: Primitive Types - Examples should return 'string' if typeof operator is used on another typeof operation.
tests.code: assert.equal(typeof typeof 2, 'string');

tests.title: when a variable is undeclared, we can use a try block and catch the reference error name to determine if it is undeclared
tests.fullTitle: determine undeclared or undefined when a variable is undeclared, we can use a try block and catch the reference error name to determine if it is undeclared

tests.title: If we know that the variable is declared, but not assigned a value, the check the value of the typeof operator to undefined
tests.fullTitle: determine undeclared or undefined If we know that the variable is declared, but not assigned a value, the check the value of the typeof operator to undefined

tests.title: Native funtions can be called with new operator in front of it or can be called as regular functions.
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Native funtions can be called with new operator in front of it or can be called as regular functions.

tests.title:
Classified into
			String
			Number
			Boolean
			Array
			Object
			RegExp
			Date
			Function
			Error
tests.fullTitle:
Native Functions Classified into
			String
			Number
			Boolean
			Array
			Object
			RegExp
			Date
			Function
			Error

tests.title: Calling with new operator creates an object wrapper around the primitive type. This can be verified using typeof operator on the newly constructed object
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Call Natives as Constructors Calling with new operator creates an object wrapper around the primitive type. This can be verified using typeof operator on the newly constructed object
tests.code:
var output = new String('abc');
assert.equal(typeof output, 'object');

tests.title: There are some caveats in calling as constructors, as it constructs object around primitives.
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Call Natives as Constructors There are some caveats in calling as constructors, as it constructs object around primitives.

tests.title: Example, false as (boolean primitive) is falsy, but false as (Boolean Object) is truthy. Calling new Boolean(false) will return empty object, which is truthy (weird!)
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Call Natives as Constructors Example, false as (boolean primitive) is falsy, but false as (Boolean Object) is truthy. Calling new Boolean(false) will return empty object, which is truthy (weird!)

tests.title: Similarly, 0 as (number primitive) is falsy, but 0 as (Number Object) is truthy. Calling new Number(0) will return empty object, which is truthy (weird!)
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Call Natives as Constructors Similarly, 0 as (number primitive) is falsy, but 0 as (Number Object) is truthy. Calling new Number(0) will return empty object, which is truthy (weird!)

tests.title: Similarly, '' as (string primitive) is falsy, but '' as (String Object) is truthy. Calling new String('') will return empty object, which is truthy (weird!)
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Call Natives as Constructors Similarly, '' as (string primitive) is falsy, but '' as (String Object) is truthy. Calling new String('') will return empty object, which is truthy (weird!)

tests.title: Hence, it is better to avoid building primitives using constructors.
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Call Natives as Constructors Hence, it is better to avoid building primitives using constructors.

tests.title: Calling as regular function creates the primitive respectively
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Call Natives as Functions Calling as regular function creates the primitive respectively
tests.code:
var output = String('abc');
assert.equal(typeof output, 'string');

tests.title: Calling as regular function will also coerce the value to its primitive type
tests.fullTitle: Native Functions Call Natives as Functions Calling as regular function will also coerce the value to its primitive type
tests.code:
var output = String(42);
assert.equal(typeof output, 'string');

tests.title: Array can be created by constructor form or literal syntax.
tests.fullTitle: Array Array can be created by constructor form or literal syntax.

tests.title: In this form, arrays can be created by using new operator
tests.fullTitle: Array Constructor Syntax In this form, arrays can be created by using new operator

tests.title: But, When called with single value like new Array(5), we would expect that it would create an array with one element of value 5. But because Array Constructor is overloaded, it creates an array with 5 empty slots instead (weird!)
tests.fullTitle: Array Constructor Syntax But, When called with single value like new Array(5), we would expect that it would create an array with one element of value 5. But because Array Constructor is overloaded, it creates an array with 5 empty slots instead (weird!)

tests.title: Hence, it is better to avoid constructor syntax due to these caveats.
tests.fullTitle: Array Constructor Syntax Hence, it is better to avoid constructor syntax due to these caveats.

tests.title: In this form, arrays can be created by using square brackets []
tests.fullTitle: Array Literal Syntax In this form, arrays can be created by using square brackets []

tests.title: It is always preferable to use the literal syntax. It reads clearly and communicates our intent in a better way.
tests.fullTitle: Array Literal Syntax It is always preferable to use the literal syntax. It reads clearly and communicates our intent in a better way.

tests.title: Object can be created by constructor form or literal syntax.
tests.fullTitle: Object Object can be created by constructor form or literal syntax.

tests.title: In this form, object can be created by using new operator. Object parameters can be added or accessed by using dot operator obj.<parameterName> or square brackets [<parameterName>]
tests.fullTitle: Object Constructor Syntax In this form, object can be created by using new operator. Object parameters can be added or accessed by using dot operator obj.<parameterName> or square brackets [<parameterName>]

tests.title: Hence, it is better to avoid constructor syntax, as it is less performant.
tests.fullTitle: Object Constructor Syntax Hence, it is better to avoid constructor syntax, as it is less performant.

tests.title: In this form, objects can be created by using curly braces {}
tests.fullTitle: Object Literal Syntax In this form, objects can be created by using curly braces {}

tests.title: It is always preferable to use the literal syntax. It reads clearly, communicates our intent in a better way and more performant.
tests.fullTitle: Object Literal Syntax It is always preferable to use the literal syntax. It reads clearly, communicates our intent in a better way and more performant.

tests.title: Regular Expression can be created by constructor form or literal syntax.
tests.fullTitle: RegExp Regular Expression can be created by constructor form or literal syntax.

tests.title: In this form, regular expression can be created by using new operator. The constructor form is useful if you want to create regular expression dynamically
tests.fullTitle: RegExp Constructor Syntax In this form, regular expression can be created by using new operator. The constructor form is useful if you want to create regular expression dynamically

tests.title: In this form, regular expression can be created by using double slashes /<Pattern>/
tests.fullTitle: RegExp Literal Syntax In this form, regular expression can be created by using double slashes /<Pattern>/

tests.title: It is always preferable to use the literal syntax. It reads clearly, communicates our intent in a better way and more performant.
tests.fullTitle: RegExp Literal Syntax It is always preferable to use the literal syntax. It reads clearly, communicates our intent in a better way and more performant.

tests.title: Date object can be created only by constructor form.
tests.fullTitle: Date Date object can be created only by constructor form.

tests.title: Functions can be created by constructor form or literal syntax (as statement or expression).
tests.fullTitle: Function Functions can be created by constructor form or literal syntax (as statement or expression).

tests.title:
Classified into
			NaN (Not a Number)
			+0
			-0
			+Infinity
			-Infinity
			null
			undefined (void)
tests.fullTitle:
Special Values Classified into
			NaN (Not a Number)
			+0
			-0
			+Infinity
			-Infinity
			null
			undefined (void)

tests.title: Whenever there is a numeric operation, if the operands are not number, the engine tries to convert it to a number. When the number conversion fails, it results in NaN. It is a special sentinel value, when the number conversion fails
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Whenever there is a numeric operation, if the operands are not number, the engine tries to convert it to a number. When the number conversion fails, it results in NaN. It is a special sentinel value, when the number conversion fails
tests.code:
var output = 'a' / 2;
assert.equal(Number.isNaN(output), true);

tests.title: typeof NaN is a number, because if we try to do numeric operation and ended in NaN, It is expected to be a number
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) typeof NaN is a number, because if we try to do numeric operation and ended in NaN, It is expected to be a number
tests.code:
var output = 'a' / 2;

assert.equal(typeof output, 'number');

tests.title: NaN when operated on any other operands will result in NaN
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) NaN when operated on any other operands will result in NaN

tests.title: It is the only value that is not equal to itself
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) It is the only value that is not equal to itself

tests.title: We need to have a way to check for NaN. It is by using global isNaN utility. But there is fatal flaw in this utility. isNaN before checking the value, it tries to converts the given value to a number and then checks to see if it resulted in NaN
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Global isNaN Utility We need to have a way to check for NaN. It is by using global isNaN utility. But there is fatal flaw in this utility. isNaN before checking the value, it tries to converts the given value to a number and then checks to see if it resulted in NaN

tests.title: returns true when used isNaN on a string. While we may expect it to give false, as given a string, we expect that isNaN('<String Value>') to be false. But it first tries to convert the string into number, and it results in NaN, so it returns true
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Global isNaN Utility returns true when used isNaN on a string. While we may expect it to give false, as given a string, we expect that isNaN('<String Value>') to be false. But it first tries to convert the string into number, and it results in NaN, so it returns true
tests.code: assert.equal(isNaN('a'), true);

tests.title: We could create a utility which works the way we think, by first checking if it is a number and then checking with isNaN utility
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Global isNaN Utility We could create a utility which works the way we think, by first checking if it is a number and then checking with isNaN utility

tests.title: We could also take advantage of the fact that NaN is the only value that is not equal to itself, to create the same utility
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Global isNaN Utility We could also take advantage of the fact that NaN is the only value that is not equal to itself, to create the same utility

tests.title: Fortunately, we have Number.isNaN() utility (added in ES6 as polyfill), which checks for NaN without converting it to a number
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Number.isNaN Utility Fortunately, we have Number.isNaN() utility (added in ES6 as polyfill), which checks for NaN without converting it to a number

tests.title: returns false when used Number.isNaN on a string
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Number.isNaN Utility returns false when used Number.isNaN on a string
tests.code: assert.equal(Number.isNaN('a'), false);

tests.title: Another way to check for NaN is to check with Object.is Utility
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Object.is Utility Another way to check for NaN is to check with Object.is Utility

tests.title: returns true when checked with NaN
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Object.is Utility returns true when checked with NaN
tests.code:
var output = 'a' / 2;

assert.equal(Object.is(output, NaN), true);

tests.title: returns false when used Object.is on a string
tests.fullTitle: NaN (Not a Number) Check for NaN Object.is Utility returns false when used Object.is on a string
tests.code: assert.equal(Object.is('a', NaN), false);

tests.title: The only way to get a negative zero (-0) would be to multiply or divide (0) by unary negate (-) operator. But we could not check for (-0) using the === operator, as we would see in the following examples
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) The only way to get a negative zero (-0) would be to multiply or divide (0) by unary negate (-) operator. But we could not check for (-0) using the === operator, as we would see in the following examples

tests.title: We could check by doing (1 / (-0)) which should result in -Infinity
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) We could check by doing (1 / (-0)) which should result in -Infinity

tests.title: We could check by using Object.is utility
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) We could check by using Object.is utility

tests.title: returns true if we check against (-0)
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) Check for (-0) === operator returns true if we check against (-0)

tests.title: Unfortunately, it returns true even if we check against (0)
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) Check for (-0) === operator Unfortunately, it returns true even if we check against (0)

tests.title: It even returns true, when we check (0) to (-0)
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) Check for (-0) === operator It even returns true, when we check (0) to (-0)
tests.code:
var output = (0 === -0);
assert.equal(output, true);

tests.title: returns true if we check against -Infinity by doing (1 / -0)
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) Check for (-0) -Infinity returns true if we check against -Infinity by doing (1 / -0)

tests.title: We could create a utility, that checks using === & -Infinity property
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) Check for (-0) -Infinity We could create a utility, that checks using === & -Infinity property

tests.title: Object.is Utility is like quadruple equals. It can be used to check -0 & NaN
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) Check for (-0) Object.is Utility Object.is Utility is like quadruple equals. It can be used to check -0 & NaN

tests.title: returns true if we check with -0
tests.fullTitle: -0 (Negative Zero) Check for (-0) Object.is Utility returns true if we check with -0
tests.code:
var output = 0 / -3;
assert.equal(Object.is(output, -0), true);

tests.title: In Javascript, there are two phases - compile & execution phase. During the compile phase, the declaration on LHS of = are compiled and references of all the variables are created in respective scopes. And then, In execution phase, RHS of = are executed and values are assigned to the variables in that scope.
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz In Javascript, there are two phases - compile & execution phase. During the compile phase, the declaration on LHS of = are compiled and references of all the variables are created in respective scopes. And then, In execution phase, RHS of = are executed and values are assigned to the variables in that scope.

tests.title: In compile phase, all the variables to LHS of = will be compiled. when baz is again declared, it would have already created reference for baz, hence it will be ignored.
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz In compile phase, all the variables to LHS of = will be compiled. when baz is again declared, it would have already created reference for baz, hence it will be ignored.

tests.title: In execution phase, output1 is assigned typeof number, output1 should be 'number', as typeof number returns 'number'
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz In execution phase, output1 is assigned typeof number, output1 should be 'number', as typeof number returns 'number'
tests.code: assert.equal(quiz.output1, 'number');

tests.title: Next, since that statement is ignored, output2 will be same as output1
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz Next, since that statement is ignored, output2 will be same as output1
tests.code: assert.equal(quiz.output2, 'number');

tests.title: Next, baz is assigned null and typeof null should return object (Note: This is bug in Javascript). Hence output3 will be equal to 'object'
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz Next, baz is assigned null and typeof null should return object (Note: This is bug in Javascript). Hence output3 will be equal to 'object'
tests.code: assert.equal(quiz.output3, 'object');

tests.title: Next, baz is assigned 'baz'*3. As (*) operator only works on numbers, it would try to convert 'baz' to a number, which would fail and result in NaN. Hence output4 will be NaN
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz Next, baz is assigned 'baz'*3. As (*) operator only works on numbers, it would try to convert 'baz' to a number, which would fail and result in NaN. Hence output4 will be NaN
tests.code: assert.equal(Number.isNaN(quiz.output4), true);

tests.title: Next then, typeof NaN would be assigned to output5, which would be 'number'
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz Next then, typeof NaN would be assigned to output5, which would be 'number'
tests.code: assert.equal(quiz.output5, 'number');

tests.title: Next, baz is assigned (1 / 0), which results in Infinity
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz Next, baz is assigned (1 / 0), which results in Infinity
tests.code: assert.equal(quiz.output6, Infinity);

tests.title: Next then, typeof Infinity is assigned to output7, which would be equal to 'number'
tests.fullTitle: Special Values Quiz Next then, typeof Infinity is assigned to output7, which would be equal to 'number'
tests.code: assert.equal(quiz.output7, 'number');

tests.title: should return 'banana' when the following expression is evaluated
tests.fullTitle: banana should return 'banana' when the following expression is evaluated
tests.code:
var output = ('b' + 'a' + + 'a' + 'a').toLowerCase();
assert.equal(output, 'banana');

tests.title: We are going to go step by step into how javascript evaluates this statement to banana, based on properties of NaN we learnt.
tests.fullTitle: banana We are going to go step by step into how javascript evaluates this statement to banana, based on properties of NaN we learnt.

tests.title:
The last before 'a' is treated as unary addition. It cannot work on strings. So, it tries to coerce to number, which fails and results in NaN
	The expression becomes 'b' + 'a' + NaN + 'a'
tests.fullTitle:
banana The last before 'a' is treated as unary addition. It cannot work on strings. So, it tries to coerce to number, which fails and results in NaN
	The expression becomes 'b' + 'a' + NaN + 'a'

tests.title:
Then other expression leads us with string concatenation.
	The expression becomes 'baNaNa'
tests.fullTitle:
banana Then other expression leads us with string concatenation.
	The expression becomes 'baNaNa'

tests.title:
The .toLowerCase() function is applied then.
	The expression becomes 'banana'
tests.fullTitle:
banana The .toLowerCase() function is applied then.
	The expression becomes 'banana'

tests.title: First, myAge will convert the age to number, which is represented in octal form
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age First, myAge will convert the age to number, which is represented in octal form

tests.title: Next, the string '39' is converted to number
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Next, the string '39' is converted to number

tests.title: Next, the string 'N/A' is converted to number. It fails and results in NaN
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Next, the string 'N/A' is converted to number. It fails and results in NaN

tests.title: Next, myAge gets subtracted from string 'my son's age', which results in NaN
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Next, myAge gets subtracted from string 'my son's age', which results in NaN
tests.code: assert.equal(Number.isNaN(outputs.output1), true);

tests.title: Next, typeof NaN is a number. NaN represents invalid number. So, the typeof NaN is always a number
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Next, typeof NaN is a number. NaN represents invalid number. So, the typeof NaN is always a number
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output2, 'number');

tests.title: Next, we compare NaN to itself. Since NaN is the only value, which is not equal to itself. we get false
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Next, we compare NaN to itself. Since NaN is the only value, which is not equal to itself. we get false
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output3, false);

tests.title: Next, we check for NaN using the global isNaN utility. When checked with a number, it results false
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Next, we check for NaN using the global isNaN utility. When checked with a number, it results false
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output4, false);

tests.title: Next, we check for NaN, which results in true. Good!
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Next, we check for NaN, which results in true. Good!
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output5, true);

tests.title: Next, we pass a normal string to check for NaN. Unfortunately it results in true. Because, before checking it tries to convert the passed value and then checks for NaN.
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Next, we pass a normal string to check for NaN. Unfortunately it results in true. Because, before checking it tries to convert the passed value and then checks for NaN.
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output6, true);

tests.title: Fortunately, we got Number.isNaN to prevent from the mistakes above. When NaN is passed, it results true
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age Fortunately, we got Number.isNaN to prevent from the mistakes above. When NaN is passed, it results true
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output7, true);

tests.title: And if normal string is passed, it results false
tests.fullTitle: Cats Age And if normal string is passed, it results false
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output8, false);

tests.title: First, trendRate is assigned negative zero (-0)
tests.fullTitle: Trend Rate First, trendRate is assigned negative zero (-0)

tests.title: Next, if we check with === -> it results true. Good
tests.fullTitle: Trend Rate Next, if we check with === -> it results true. Good
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output1, true);

tests.title: Next, when we try to convert to string, we get zero (weird!)
tests.fullTitle: Trend Rate Next, when we try to convert to string, we get zero (weird!)
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output2, 0);

tests.title: Next, when we check with (0), it results in true (Not Good!)
tests.fullTitle: Trend Rate Next, when we check with (0), it results in true (Not Good!)
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output3, true);

tests.title: Next, again when checked < or >, it results in false. (-0) is neither greater than (0) or less than (0). Not Good again!
tests.fullTitle: Trend Rate Next, again when checked < or >, it results in false. (-0) is neither greater than (0) or less than (0). Not Good again!
tests.code:
assert.equal(outputs.output4, false);
assert.equal(outputs.output5, false);

tests.title: Fortunately, we got Object.is to check for correct (-0) value. when passed (0) it returns false
tests.fullTitle: Trend Rate Fortunately, we got Object.is to check for correct (-0) value. when passed (0) it returns false
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output6, false);

tests.title: Next, if we pass (-0), we get true. Good!
tests.fullTitle: Trend Rate Next, if we pass (-0), we get true. Good!
tests.code: assert.equal(outputs.output7, true);

tests.title: Internally in Javascript, Whenever there is need for coercion, the abstract methods are dispatched to do the coercion. The following are some methods.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations Internally in Javascript, Whenever there is need for coercion, the abstract methods are dispatched to do the coercion. The following are some methods.

tests.title:
ToString
			ToNumber
			ToBoolean
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToString
			ToNumber
			ToBoolean

tests.title: It is important to note that, these methods are different from methods like toString (lowercase). Instead of getting into details like how these methods work, we can focus on what is end result of calling such abstract operations.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations It is important to note that, these methods are different from methods like toString (lowercase). Instead of getting into details like how these methods work, we can focus on what is end result of calling such abstract operations.

tests.title: ToString method converts the given value to a string primitive. The following are some end results during the conversion.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString method converts the given value to a string primitive. The following are some end results during the conversion.

tests.title:
null 		-> 	'null'
					undefined 	-> 	'undefined'
					true 		-> 	'true'
					false 		-> 	'false'
					3.1459 		-> 	'3.1459'
					0 			-> 	'0'
					-0 			-> 	'0'
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Primitives null 		-> 	'null'
					undefined 	-> 	'undefined'
					true 		-> 	'true'
					false 		-> 	'false'
					3.1459 		-> 	'3.1459'
					0 			-> 	'0'
					-0 			-> 	'0'

tests.title: It is important to note that (-0) becomes ('0') because it internally tries to hide the fact that there is no negative zero.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Primitives It is important to note that (-0) becomes ('0') because it internally tries to hide the fact that there is no negative zero.

tests.title: ToString method when called on a non-primitive, dispatches the default toString method on the object or toString method which was defined by us.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives ToString method when called on a non-primitive, dispatches the default toString method on the object or toString method which was defined by us.

tests.title: When called on array or object, it calls ToPrimitive to convert the object into a primitive, and then it calls ToString abstract operation.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives When called on array or object, it calls ToPrimitive to convert the object into a primitive, and then it calls ToString abstract operation.

tests.title: The following are some of the conversions in the default toString method when called on arrays.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives The following are some of the conversions in the default toString method when called on arrays.

tests.title:
[] 					-> 	''
					[1,2,3] 			-> 	'1,2,3'
					[null, undefined] 	-> 	','
					[ [ [],[],[] ], [] ]-> 	',,,'
					[,,,,] 				-> 	',,,'
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives [] 					-> 	''
					[1,2,3] 			-> 	'1,2,3'
					[null, undefined] 	-> 	','
					[ [ [],[],[] ], [] ]-> 	',,,'
					[,,,,] 				-> 	',,,'

tests.title: It is counter-intuitive for us to think that [] becomes ''. We do not know if that came from empty string or array. It could have become '[]' string with array symbol, but it does not. Similarly array with [1,2,3] becomes '1,2,3', which could have become '[1,2,3]' with the square brackets, but it does not (weird but important!)
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives It is counter-intuitive for us to think that [] becomes ''. We do not know if that came from empty string or array. It could have become '[]' string with array symbol, but it does not. Similarly array with [1,2,3] becomes '1,2,3', which could have become '[1,2,3]' with the square brackets, but it does not (weird but important!)

tests.title: More importantly, when null & undefined are individually stringified, it becomes 'null' & 'undefined', but when in an array, it becomes ',' (weird!)
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives More importantly, when null & undefined are individually stringified, it becomes 'null' & 'undefined', but when in an array, it becomes ',' (weird!)

tests.title: In Arrays, trailing commas are allowed, hence [,,,,] becomes ',,,'
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives In Arrays, trailing commas are allowed, hence [,,,,] becomes ',,,'

tests.title: The following are some of the conversions in the default toString method when called on objects.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives The following are some of the conversions in the default toString method when called on objects.

tests.title:
{}		-> 	'[object Object]'
					{a:2} 	-> 	'[object Object]'
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives {}		-> 	'[object Object]'
					{a:2} 	-> 	'[object Object]'

tests.title: During conversion, the contents of the objects are not shown.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives During conversion, the contents of the objects are not shown.

tests.title: The Object (uppercase) can be changed using ES6 meta programming, Refer ES6 Right parts course for more information.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives The Object (uppercase) can be changed using ES6 meta programming, Refer ES6 Right parts course for more information.

tests.title:
When ToPrimitive is called on an object, the following methods are called in the specific order,
							1. toString()
							2. valueOf()

						If the first method does not return a primitive, then it calls the second method.
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToString ToString on Non-Primitives ToPrimitive When ToPrimitive is called on an object, the following methods are called in the specific order,
							1. toString()
							2. valueOf()

						If the first method does not return a primitive, then it calls the second method.

tests.title: ToNumber method converts the given value to a number primitive. The following are some end results during the conversion.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber method converts the given value to a number primitive. The following are some end results during the conversion.

tests.title:
'' 		-> 	0
					'0' 		-> 	0
					'-0' 		-> 	-0
					'  009  ' 	-> 	9
					'3.1459' 	-> 	3.1459
					'0.' 		-> 	0
					'.0' 		-> 	0
					'.' 		-> 	NaN
					'0xaf' 		-> 	175
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on string primitive '' 		-> 	0
					'0' 		-> 	0
					'-0' 		-> 	-0
					'  009  ' 	-> 	9
					'3.1459' 	-> 	3.1459
					'0.' 		-> 	0
					'.0' 		-> 	0
					'.' 		-> 	NaN
					'0xaf' 		-> 	175

tests.title: Refer JS Deep Foundations course for more information.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on string primitive Refer JS Deep Foundations course for more information.

tests.title:
false 		-> 	0
					true 		-> 	1
					null 		-> 	0
					undefined 	-> 	NaN
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on boolean, null, undefined false 		-> 	0
					true 		-> 	1
					null 		-> 	0
					undefined 	-> 	NaN

tests.title: Refer JS Deep Foundations course for more information.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on boolean, null, undefined Refer JS Deep Foundations course for more information.

tests.title: When called on array or object, it calls ToPrimitive to convert the object into a primitive, and then it calls ToNumber abstract operation.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on array or object When called on array or object, it calls ToPrimitive to convert the object into a primitive, and then it calls ToNumber abstract operation.

tests.title: The following are some of the conversions for arrays by ToNumber abstract operation
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on array or object The following are some of the conversions for arrays by ToNumber abstract operation

tests.title:
[''] 		-> 	0
					['0'] 		-> 	0
					['-0'] 		-> 	-0
					[null] 		-> 	0
					[undefined] -> 	0
					[1,2,3] 	-> 	NaN
					[[[[]]]] 	-> 	0
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on array or object [''] 		-> 	0
					['0'] 		-> 	0
					['-0'] 		-> 	-0
					[null] 		-> 	0
					[undefined] -> 	0
					[1,2,3] 	-> 	NaN
					[[[[]]]] 	-> 	0

tests.title: Refer JS Deep Foundations course for more information.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on array or object Refer JS Deep Foundations course for more information.

tests.title:
When ToPrimitive is called on an object, the following methods are called in the specific order,
							1. valueOf()
							2. toString()

						If the first method does not return a primitive, then it calls the second method.
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToNumber ToNumber on array or object ToPrimitive When ToPrimitive is called on an object, the following methods are called in the specific order,
							1. valueOf()
							2. toString()

						If the first method does not return a primitive, then it calls the second method.

tests.title: ToBoolean method converts the given value to a boolean primitive. To understand what ToBoolean does, we need to understand truthy and falsy values.
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToBoolean ToBoolean method converts the given value to a boolean primitive. To understand what ToBoolean does, we need to understand truthy and falsy values.

tests.title:
When ToBoolean abstract operation is called, the following values results in false boolean primitive
				'', "", ``
				0, +0, -0
				null
				NaN
				false
				undefined
tests.fullTitle:
Abstract Operations ToBoolean When ToBoolean abstract operation is called, the following values results in false boolean primitive
				'', "", ``
				0, +0, -0
				null
				NaN
				false
				undefined

tests.title: All the OTHER values except the above values converts to true boolean primitive, when ToBoolean abstract operation is called. So If we need to know whether something is truthy, check it in the falsy list, If it is not there - then it is truthy
tests.fullTitle: Abstract Operations ToBoolean All the OTHER values except the above values converts to true boolean primitive, when ToBoolean abstract operation is called. So If we need to know whether something is truthy, check it in the falsy list, If it is not there - then it is truthy

tests.title: Coercion can be categorized into explicit & implicit. More importantly, it is a style. We can't decide that explicit is good & implicit is bad. There are two mechanisms which can be used. The decision lies in the fact that the code should be more readable & understandable by all (or most) developers.
tests.fullTitle: Coercion Types Coercion can be categorized into explicit & implicit. More importantly, it is a style. We can't decide that explicit is good & implicit is bad. There are two mechanisms which can be used. The decision lies in the fact that the code should be more readable & understandable by all (or most) developers.

tests.title: We are going to go step by step into how javascript evaluates this statement to true.
tests.fullTitle: Coercion Types We are going to go step by step into how javascript evaluates this statement to true.

tests.title: Explicit Coercion implies that it is obvious from the code that we are trying to do the coercion.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Explicit Coercion implies that it is obvious from the code that we are trying to do the coercion.

tests.title: Of all the methods mentioned below, using the Native Function for conversion should be preferred, as it cleaner & communicates our intent clearly.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Of all the methods mentioned below, using the Native Function for conversion should be preferred, as it cleaner & communicates our intent clearly.

tests.title: We have a lot of use cases for converting string into number. There are a couple of ways to do it.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number We have a lot of use cases for converting string into number. There are a couple of ways to do it.

tests.title: parseInt is generally used in javascript to convert the given string into a number. But it is quite different from directly coercing the given value.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number parseInt parseInt is generally used in javascript to convert the given string into a number. But it is quite different from directly coercing the given value.

tests.title: It literally parses the given value from left to right to find the numerical characters & stops when a non-numerical character starts. For Eg: when we give it a string '123px', it starts from left to right to collect the input and immediately stops once the parser hits the letter 'p'.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number parseInt It literally parses the given value from left to right to find the numerical characters & stops when a non-numerical character starts. For Eg: when we give it a string '123px', it starts from left to right to collect the input and immediately stops once the parser hits the letter 'p'.

tests.title: This mechanism may result in unpredictable or undesirable results.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number parseInt This mechanism may result in unpredictable or undesirable results.

tests.title: It parses and converts '123px' to number primitive 123
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number parseInt It parses and converts '123px' to number primitive 123

tests.title: Unlike parseInt, it is either convert or not convert at all. There is no parsing like parseInt. When the conversion fails it results in NaN.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number Number() Native Function Unlike parseInt, it is either convert or not convert at all. There is no parsing like parseInt. When the conversion fails it results in NaN.

tests.title: when given a value like '123px', it fails and results in NaN
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number Number() Native Function when given a value like '123px', it fails and results in NaN

tests.title: It can be used to convert a given value into a number primitive, and it runs the ToNumber abstract operation.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number Number() Native Function It can be used to convert a given value into a number primitive, and it runs the ToNumber abstract operation.

tests.title: successfully converts the given value to a number primitive
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number Number() Native Function successfully converts the given value to a number primitive

tests.title: The Unary (+) operator when operated on operands tries to convert it to number primitive by running the ToNumber abstract operation.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number Unary (+) operator The Unary (+) operator when operated on operands tries to convert it to number primitive by running the ToNumber abstract operation.

tests.title: It may not look like explicit, Maybe we think of it as explicitly implicit.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number Unary (+) operator It may not look like explicit, Maybe we think of it as explicitly implicit.

tests.title: converts the given value to a number primitive
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion string -> number Unary (+) operator converts the given value to a number primitive

tests.title: We have a lot of use cases for converting number into string. There are a couple of ways to do it.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion number -> string We have a lot of use cases for converting number into string. There are a couple of ways to do it.

tests.title: toString is actually a method. Then we would expect it not to operate on a primitive. But actually it works (yay!). When the toString method is called on a primitive, it converts the primitive into its object wrapper (implicit) and then calls the method (explicit). It is called boxing
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion number -> string toString toString is actually a method. Then we would expect it not to operate on a primitive. But actually it works (yay!). When the toString method is called on a primitive, it converts the primitive into its object wrapper (implicit) and then calls the method (explicit). It is called boxing

tests.title: We think of it as explicitly implicit.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion number -> string toString We think of it as explicitly implicit.

tests.title: converts the given value to a string primitive
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion number -> string toString converts the given value to a string primitive

tests.title: It can be used to convert a given value into a number primitive, and it runs the ToNumber abstract operation.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion number -> string String() Native Function It can be used to convert a given value into a number primitive, and it runs the ToNumber abstract operation.

tests.title: converts the given value to a string primitive
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion number -> string String() Native Function converts the given value to a string primitive

tests.title: We have a lot of use cases for converting any primitive type into boolean. There are a couple of ways to do it.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean We have a lot of use cases for converting any primitive type into boolean. There are a couple of ways to do it.

tests.title: It can be used to convert a given value into a boolean primitive, and it runs the ToBoolean abstract operation.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean Boolean() Native Function It can be used to convert a given value into a boolean primitive, and it runs the ToBoolean abstract operation.

tests.title: converts the given value to a boolean primitive
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean Boolean() Native Function converts the given value to a boolean primitive

tests.title: By seeing the double negate, it is easy to believe that there is a actually a double negate operator. But there is no such thing.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean (!!) Double Negate Operator By seeing the double negate, it is easy to believe that there is a actually a double negate operator. But there is no such thing.

tests.title:
The following happens when double negate operator is operated,
					1. The first negate operator tries to converts the given value to a boolean and then negates its value (implicit).
					2. The second negate flips its value to give us the correct boolean value (explicit).
tests.fullTitle:
Explicit Coercion * -> boolean (!!) Double Negate Operator The following happens when double negate operator is operated,
					1. The first negate operator tries to converts the given value to a boolean and then negates its value (implicit).
					2. The second negate flips its value to give us the correct boolean value (explicit).

tests.title: We think of it as explicitly implicit.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean (!!) Double Negate Operator We think of it as explicitly implicit.

tests.title: converts the given value to a boolean primitive. When tried to coerce to a boolean, [] results in true, because it is not in the falsy list. Refer to ToBoolean abstract operation.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean (!!) Double Negate Operator converts the given value to a boolean primitive. When tried to coerce to a boolean, [] results in true, because it is not in the falsy list. Refer to ToBoolean abstract operation.

tests.title: When ternary operator is operated on a value, it first tries to coerce it to a boolean primitive & then it checks to value to determine true or false.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean (?:) Ternary Operator When ternary operator is operated on a value, it first tries to coerce it to a boolean primitive & then it checks to value to determine true or false.

tests.title: We think of it as explicitly implicit.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean (?:) Ternary Operator We think of it as explicitly implicit.

tests.title: converts the given value to a boolean primitive
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion * -> boolean (?:) Ternary Operator converts the given value to a boolean primitive

tests.title: There is no literal syntax for creating date objects. We have to use the new Date() to create a date object. For most use cases, we need to get the current time in unix time stamp.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples Date There is no literal syntax for creating date objects. We have to use the new Date() to create a date object. For most use cases, we need to get the current time in unix time stamp.

tests.title: It turns out that the date object when coerced to a number returns the current time in unix timestamp. Also there is a utility Date.now() which also returns the current time. The usage of Number native function clearly communicates our intent, rather than using unary (+) operator. Hence native functions should be preferred in this case.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples Date It turns out that the date object when coerced to a number returns the current time in unix timestamp. Also there is a utility Date.now() which also returns the current time. The usage of Number native function clearly communicates our intent, rather than using unary (+) operator. Hence native functions should be preferred in this case.

tests.title: It is notable that parseInt cannot be used to parse the number from the date object, because new Date() returns string value, which when parsed returns NaN
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples Date It is notable that parseInt cannot be used to parse the number from the date object, because new Date() returns string value, which when parsed returns NaN
tests.code:
var dateByCoercion1 = parseInt(new Date(), 10);
assert.equal(Number.isNaN(dateByCoercion1), true);

tests.title: We use indexOf method to see whether there is a substring in a given string, if found, it returns the index of the character or it returns (-1)
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples indexOf (-1) -> ~ Operator We use indexOf method to see whether there is a substring in a given string, if found, it returns the index of the character or it returns (-1)

tests.title: The problem with (-1) is that it is a truthy value, because it is not in falsy list. So if we need to check for true/false, we would need to use === -1. Maybe a sensible result of such functions like indexOf is either false or NaN. But we do not get that.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples indexOf (-1) -> ~ Operator The problem with (-1) is that it is a truthy value, because it is not in falsy list. So if we need to check for true/false, we would need to use === -1. Maybe a sensible result of such functions like indexOf is either false or NaN. But we do not get that.

tests.title: An alternate approach is to use (~) operator. The (~) operator when operated, adds one to it and negates the value ~x -> -(x+1). It is called one's complement.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples indexOf (-1) -> ~ Operator An alternate approach is to use (~) operator. The (~) operator when operated, adds one to it and negates the value ~x -> -(x+1). It is called one's complement.

tests.title: Using the above property, if the return value of a function is (-1) then ~(-1) would result in (-0) as shown ~(-1) -> -(-1+1) -> -0. Since (-0) is falsy, we could use it as a boolean primitive (yay!).
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples indexOf (-1) -> ~ Operator Using the above property, if the return value of a function is (-1) then ~(-1) would result in (-0) as shown ~(-1) -> -(-1+1) -> -0. Since (-0) is falsy, we could use it as a boolean primitive (yay!).

tests.title: Even though, the syntax is very concise, if some developer were to read this, it is harder to understand what the (~) operator does & why it is used in such a way.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples indexOf (-1) -> ~ Operator Even though, the syntax is very concise, if some developer were to read this, it is harder to understand what the (~) operator does & why it is used in such a way.

tests.title: As of ES6, there is a utility includes() which behaves exactly as we would expect. It returns a boolean when checked for a substring in a string.
tests.fullTitle: Explicit Coercion Examples indexOf (-1) -> ~ Operator As of ES6, there is a utility includes() which behaves exactly as we would expect. It returns a boolean when checked for a substring in a string.

tests.title: Implicit Coercion implies that result happens as a side effect of other operation. It is as if we say we want the end result to happen. But don't care how it happens. Let the computer decide how it should be performed. That doesn't mean that it is all bad. We should make an informed decision about how clearly we are communicating our intent.
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion Implicit Coercion implies that result happens as a side effect of other operation. It is as if we say we want the end result to happen. But don't care how it happens. Let the computer decide how it should be performed. That doesn't mean that it is all bad. We should make an informed decision about how clearly we are communicating our intent.

tests.title: We want to convert a string to a number primitive in an implicit way. Like doing a mathematical operation which doesn't have any effect on the original value. The following are some examples
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion string -> number We want to convert a string to a number primitive in an implicit way. Like doing a mathematical operation which doesn't have any effect on the original value. The following are some examples

tests.title: Subtracting with (0). The minus operator (-) is designed specifically to deal with numbers. When operated on values other than numbers, it tries to coerce the value to a number and then subtracts zero (like a no-operation) from it
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion string -> number Subtracting with (0). The minus operator (-) is designed specifically to deal with numbers. When operated on values other than numbers, it tries to coerce the value to a number and then subtracts zero (like a no-operation) from it

tests.title: In a similar way, subtracting with '0' would also give back the same result. In this case it would also try to coerce '0' to a number. As a matter of fact, subtracting with empty string '' will also work
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion string -> number In a similar way, subtracting with '0' would also give back the same result. In this case it would also try to coerce '0' to a number. As a matter of fact, subtracting with empty string '' will also work

tests.title: In a similar way, dividing by one also would give the same result
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion string -> number In a similar way, dividing by one also would give the same result

tests.title: We should never do the coercion this way, as it doesn't convey our intentions correctly. But we should be aware of this.
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion string -> number We should never do the coercion this way, as it doesn't convey our intentions correctly. But we should be aware of this.

tests.title: Following are some of the ways, in which we convert number to string in an implicit way
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion number -> string Following are some of the ways, in which we convert number to string in an implicit way

tests.title: Adding number with string. The (+) operator is designed to do mathematical addition. But if one of the operands is a string, then it prefers string concatenation. So it tries to convert the other operand into a string and adds the empty string (like no-operation) to it.
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion number -> string Adding number with string. The (+) operator is designed to do mathematical addition. But if one of the operands is a string, then it prefers string concatenation. So it tries to convert the other operand into a string and adds the empty string (like no-operation) to it.

tests.title: Doing the same with (-) operator will not work, because there is no preference for string concatenation in (-) operator as it is in (+) operator. So it converts the operands to a number '' -> 0 and hence the coercion will not happen
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion number -> string Doing the same with (-) operator will not work, because there is no preference for string concatenation in (-) operator as it is in (+) operator. So it converts the operands to a number '' -> 0 and hence the coercion will not happen

tests.title: Whenever we write an if statement, the value is implicitly coerced to a boolean value. The following are some examples
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean Whenever we write an if statement, the value is implicitly coerced to a boolean value. The following are some examples

tests.title: Implicit coercion happens in an if statement. If any value that is not on the falsy list is passed to if statement, it passes
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean Implicit coercion happens in an if statement. If any value that is not on the falsy list is passed to if statement, it passes

tests.title: Similarly, if we pass anything in the falsy list, then it evaluates to false
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean Similarly, if we pass anything in the falsy list, then it evaluates to false

tests.title: But, things start to act weird if we use (==) operator. If (==) operator is used to compare to a boolean value, it tries to convert both the operands to number. (==) PREFERS to checks numbers (IMPORTANT!). Hence when the statement ('123' == true) is executed, (==) operator coerces the operands to number primitives. So ('123' == true) -> (123 == 1), which results in false (weird!)
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean But, things start to act weird if we use (==) operator. If (==) operator is used to compare to a boolean value, it tries to convert both the operands to number. (==) PREFERS to checks numbers (IMPORTANT!). Hence when the statement ('123' == true) is executed, (==) operator coerces the operands to number primitives. So ('123' == true) -> (123 == 1), which results in false (weird!)

tests.title: Sometimes, it leads to a happy accident. In this case also, (==) prefers numbers and hence coerces '' to 0 and false to 0 ('' == false) -> (0 == 0), which results in true, but only as a happy accident (IMPORTANT!)
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean Sometimes, it leads to a happy accident. In this case also, (==) prefers numbers and hence coerces '' to 0 and false to 0 ('' == false) -> (0 == 0), which results in true, but only as a happy accident (IMPORTANT!)

tests.title: Similarly, Implicit coercion happens on objects as well. If an empty array [] is passed to an if statement, it tries to coerce it to a boolean meaning it calls ToBoolean abstract operation, which results in true, because [] is not in the falsy list
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean Similarly, Implicit coercion happens on objects as well. If an empty array [] is passed to an if statement, it tries to coerce it to a boolean meaning it calls ToBoolean abstract operation, which results in true, because [] is not in the falsy list

tests.title: But, if we start using (==) operator on checking the objects, we get strange results. In this case we check ([] == true). As mentioned earlier, (==) prefers to check numbers, hence it coerces it's operands to its number primitive. So [] becomes 0 & true becomes 1 ([] == true) -> (0 == 1) which results in false
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean But, if we start using (==) operator on checking the objects, we get strange results. In this case we check ([] == true). As mentioned earlier, (==) prefers to check numbers, hence it coerces it's operands to its number primitive. So [] becomes 0 & true becomes 1 ([] == true) -> (0 == 1) which results in false

tests.title: Implicit coercion also happens in (&&) operator. They act as a selection operators. It tries to evaluate the first operand if it is true, then it selects the other operand value or else selects the first operand value. In this case, it evaluates the empty string '', converting it to boolean results in false and hence first operand's value '' is selected and stored in output1 variable. For the next case, it evaluates the string '123', converting it to boolean results in true and hence the second operand's value is selected and stored in output2 variable.
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean Implicit coercion also happens in (&&) operator. They act as a selection operators. It tries to evaluate the first operand if it is true, then it selects the other operand value or else selects the first operand value. In this case, it evaluates the empty string '', converting it to boolean results in false and hence first operand's value '' is selected and stored in output1 variable. For the next case, it evaluates the string '123', converting it to boolean results in true and hence the second operand's value is selected and stored in output2 variable.

tests.title: Implicit coercion also happens in (||) operator. They act as a selection operators. It tries to evaluate the first operand if it is true, then it selects that value or else selects the other value. In this case, it evaluates the empty string '', converting it to boolean results in false and hence other operand's value 'a' is selected and stored in output variable
tests.fullTitle: Implicit Coercion * -> boolean Implicit coercion also happens in (||) operator. They act as a selection operators. It tries to evaluate the first operand if it is true, then it selects that value or else selects the other value. In this case, it evaluates the empty string '', converting it to boolean results in false and hence other operand's value 'a' is selected and stored in output variable

tests.title:
Since (==) operator prefers to do number comparison and not boolean coercion as we would expect, we usually get strange results. Hence it is better to avoid (==) in the following cases
				* boolean comparisons (== true or == false)
				* comparisons to either [], '' or 0
tests.fullTitle:
Implicit Coercion * -> boolean Since (==) operator prefers to do number comparison and not boolean coercion as we would expect, we usually get strange results. Hence it is better to avoid (==) in the following cases
				* boolean comparisons (== true or == false)
				* comparisons to either [], '' or 0

tests.title: Coercion Grid is table which has all the cases indicating what the value coerces into. It serves as a guideline to what to expect if a coercion happens on that kind of value.
tests.fullTitle: Coercion Grid Coercion Grid is table which has all the cases indicating what the value coerces into. It serves as a guideline to what to expect if a coercion happens on that kind of value.

tests.title: There are two files - coercion-grid-WTF.png & coercion-grid-fixed.png
tests.fullTitle: Coercion Grid There are two files - coercion-grid-WTF.png & coercion-grid-fixed.png

tests.title: It shows what are all the bad coercions in javascript. It is important to understand these to get predictable results. Even though we know it is non-sense, that's how the language is designed. Knowing the corner cases would help in getting predictable results.
tests.fullTitle: Coercion Grid coercion-grid-WTF It shows what are all the bad coercions in javascript. It is important to understand these to get predictable results. Even though we know it is non-sense, that's how the language is designed. Knowing the corner cases would help in getting predictable results.

tests.title: It shows what if we fixed all the coercion bugs. What if we correctly coerce it to the value we think. Those values are included in this list.
tests.fullTitle: Coercion Grid coercion-grid-fixed It shows what if we fixed all the coercion bugs. What if we correctly coerce it to the value we think. Those values are included in this list.

tests.title: As mentioned earlier, (==) operator prefers to compare number rather than comparing boolean. In this example, when the following statement is executed [] == ![], it results in true (weird!)
tests.fullTitle: [] == ![] results true As mentioned earlier, (==) operator prefers to compare number rather than comparing boolean. In this example, when the following statement is executed [] == ![], it results in true (weird!)

tests.title: We are going to go step by step into how javascript evaluates this statement to true, based on all the rules we learnt.
tests.fullTitle: [] == ![] results true We are going to go step by step into how javascript evaluates this statement to true, based on all the rules we learnt.

tests.title: Initially, when the statement is executed, there is an operator precedence. So the negate operator (!) gets precedence and it operates on []. Since (!) operator only operates on boolean primitive and since [] is an object, it calls ToBoolean abstract operation, which results in true, because [] is not in the falsy list. So now it becomes ( [] == !true ). It now is operated by (!) operated which results in false ( [] == false ).
tests.fullTitle: [] == ![] results true Initially, when the statement is executed, there is an operator precedence. So the negate operator (!) gets precedence and it operates on []. Since (!) operator only operates on boolean primitive and since [] is an object, it calls ToBoolean abstract operation, which results in true, because [] is not in the falsy list. So now it becomes ( [] == !true ). It now is operated by (!) operated which results in false ( [] == false ).

tests.title: Next, Since (==) operator prefers to do number comparison, the array [] on the LHS is to be converted to number primitive by ToNumber abstract operation. Since [] is an object, it runs ToPrimitive first, which results in '' ( '' == false). Now it runs ToNumber on it to get 0 ( 0 == false)
tests.fullTitle: [] == ![] results true Next, Since (==) operator prefers to do number comparison, the array [] on the LHS is to be converted to number primitive by ToNumber abstract operation. Since [] is an object, it runs ToPrimitive first, which results in '' ( '' == false). Now it runs ToNumber on it to get 0 ( 0 == false)

tests.title: Next, it tries to convert the RHS to the number, which results in 0 ( 0 == 0 ), which in turn gives us true
tests.fullTitle: [] == ![] results true Next, it tries to convert the RHS to the number, which results in 0 ( 0 == 0 ), which in turn gives us true

tests.title:
To summarize, following are the steps
			1. [] == ![]
			2. [] == !true 	(Negate precedence -> ToBoolean -> true (as it is not in falsy list))
			3. [] == false 	(Negate operator)
			4. '' == false 	([] -> == operator -> ToNumber -> ToPrimitive -> '')
			5. 0  == false 	('' -> ToNumber -> 0)
			6. 0  == 0 		(false -> ToNumber -> 0)
			7. true
tests.fullTitle:
[] == ![] results true To summarize, following are the steps
			1. [] == ![]
			2. [] == !true 	(Negate precedence -> ToBoolean -> true (as it is not in falsy list))
			3. [] == false 	(Negate operator)
			4. '' == false 	([] -> == operator -> ToNumber -> ToPrimitive -> '')
			5. 0  == false 	('' -> ToNumber -> 0)
			6. 0  == 0 		(false -> ToNumber -> 0)
			7. true

tests.title: It is more predictable, if we follow the steps that are written in specs, because it is what the javascript does. Even though it might seem counter-intuitive in some cases, if we know the rules, we can predict it beforehand.
tests.fullTitle: [] == ![] results true It is more predictable, if we follow the steps that are written in specs, because it is what the javascript does. Even though it might seem counter-intuitive in some cases, if we know the rules, we can predict it beforehand.
